• Print!
  • Sand the top of the small cones that mate into the holes if necessary.
  • Sand the inside of the cone and clip pieces to get a slightly snug fit on the end cylinder.
  • Glue and paint.
  • Hunt down and destroy the Jedi.
    • Order of assembly (looking left to right) is: Hilt - middle - end cylinder - clip - half cone. Clip and half cone slide over the end cylinder. Make sure you print with at least 2 shells to improve the strength of it. 25% fill on my Cupcake seems to work well.

I really liked bpainter's original design for this stabilizer because I did not want to drill into my frame, but my one issue with it was that the bed carriage would bump it when I would get close to y-max. I have remixed it to use a zip-tie to clamp down on the frame and provide a little extra clearance. The bed carriage will ever so slightly scrape the zip-tie, but it is much further into the travel of the bed and has much less impact.

Printer:

Maker Select V2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

35%

Instructions

Run a zip-tie through from the bottom of the interior side and loop it over and back around. I had originally planned to make the notch at the top where the head of the zip-tie would rest, but I didn't make it quite big enough for my zip-ties.

I used a 30mm M5 bolt to attach it to the pulley frame, which worked out just about perfect.

description.text: This is the original and best known of the sandwich complexes, ferrocene. It is composed of an iron atom "sandwiched" between two aromatic five-membered rings. This model was created from the cif data deposited with the CCDC for Brock and Fu, Acta. Cryst B., 1997, Vol 53, page 928.
This was printed in ABS on an UP! printer with support enabled.

author: prichey

description.text:
Turn the handle, and soak in the applause. Maybe you aced a test, or you told a good joke. Whatever the reason, you deserve it. My first attempt at a complicated design. The tolerance on my printer isn't so good, so I had to design all the connections with this in mind. Designed in OpenSCAD. Printed on a 6" Prusa i3 (Makerfarm). I may make some modifications to make the arms a little more stable, but it works pretty well as is. Here's a video of it in action:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=s9paA0o07t4

I'm not sure how obvious the setup is, since I've been staring at all these pieces for weeks. If you need help assembling, please let me know. Print out parts1, arms and conns. I only have a 6" bed, so I had to split it up. The individual pieces are as follow:
  • the base
  • the wheel
  • the handle on the wheel
  • the arms(2)
  • the base / arms connectors (2) (separate stl file)
  • the wheel / arm connector
  • the arms pin
  • the hands (2)
  • the foot (base stabilizer)
    • Assembly:
  • snap handle into wheel.
  • attach foot to base
  • snap wheel onto base
  • insert base / arm connectors into base
  • connect base / arm connectors to loops in arms
  • snap arms onto arm pin
  • slip arm pin into base groove
  • snap one end of wheel / arm connector onto handle and the other onto the arm pin
  • attach hands
    • Then spin the handle.

description.text:
Part that adds the Emerson wave feature to the Spyderco Tenacious knife. Still permits opening via the 1/2" hole.

Reference images for the Tenacious' shape & the Emerson wave protrusion.

I will try & add a thumbstud too so that users can open it using 1) the Spyderco hole, 2) the thumbstud, or 3) the Emerson Wave without each interfering with the other. I will make a version with a curved thumbstud like (https://kershaw.kaiusaltd.com/knives/knife/black-blur), a regular thumbstud, & eventually thumbstuds on both sides.

I haven't checked the fit on this at all. I imagine filing will be necessary. I have milled this design out with 1/4" aluminum about 12 times using a dremel (do not recommend, takes 2-3 hours each time), & this would be a perfect design for CNC milling, though read below about affixing it.

12 Dec 2016: still in progress since I can't think of a satisfactory wave to fix it onto the knife. I was thinking of using a set screw or something similar. Probably indefinitely on hold. Contact me if you have any ideas.

author: TrushinaOV

description.text:
I hated how the Suntour Command Shifters are impossible to get & no good mass-produced version is offered. I never used them, but they look very intuitive & like a good design. These are Inventor files, not Solidworks as I'm used to. I might redesign them in Solidworks. I used Inventor first because I liked their sketched spline feature a lot more at the time for tracing over the reference images (provided).

This project has kind of gotten forgotten lately. If people have more interest, I might revive it, but for the moment it's available for anyone who wants to try & pick up where I left off. It's just not a priority at the moment.

I have never printed these out for testing/fitting purposes. If you do, please let me know so I can modify/update them as necessary.

The Kelly Take-offs don't look that great in my opinion, & the WTB whifter pod (https://www.google.com/search?q=wtb+shifter+pod&rlz=1C1CHBD_enUS706US706&tbm=isch&tbo=u&source=univ&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwj77Irio-_QAhUEilQKHdyeC0MQsAQIGw&biw=1270&bih=1330 also discontinued, I might try & design these too) might be okay. I prefer having the extended levers on both sides.

  • https://f.ptcdn.info/792/012/000/1385834440-6306127540-o.jpg
  • http://forums.mtbr.com/vintage-retro-classic/wtb-drop-bar-shifter-adapter-question-842690.html
  • http://forum.cyclinguk.org/viewtopic.php?f=5&t=57027&start=15
  • http://www.tririg.com/articles.php?id=2011_01_Easton_Aerobars&page=2
  • http://forum.cyclinguk.org/viewtopic.php?f=5&t=57027&hilit=lamp&start=105
  • http://forum.cyclinguk.org/viewtopic.php?f=5&t=57027&start=90

They currently attach to the handlebars using a hose clamp, which might not even exist. I'm not sure. A 4 mm bolt will affix the shifter to the pod unit, though I forget if I added a nut on the other side. I don't want the bolt to gouge the handlebar.

author: snelleluc

description.text:
http://www.tektro-usa.com/category.php?catid=188&productid=1096 A few versions of this, a Tektro "Adjustable Fork Crown Cable Hanger"

My reference image is provided. The first version is almost an identical copy.

They are sized so that any standard brake barrel adjuster will fit. A cutout (added feature not present on the original) is provided to make the installation/removal of the cable much faster. They will not screw in, & don't force them too. Using the locknut, you can achieve the same adjustment effect without threading these pieces together. I haven't tested how they do under vibration/long rides, & neither should you, unless you machine them. If you are, resize that hole to be appropriately small & tap the hole.

The only thing that ended up worked was the fourth version, but that mounted to a pretty particular steel piece that used to be a reflector mount. I bent this piece into shape, then mounted the 4th version to that with a 5 mm bolt & locknut. It was pretty difficult to bend the steel piece by hand, but when I mounted it, applying the front brake easily bent the steel bracket (though not permanently, & not enough that the brake felt weird at the lever). I do not recommend this either. The plastic whitened, indicating some wear at the 90 deg bend, but it never broke. I took it off before that may have happened. I'm not even going to show you how this version came together because I don't recommend it. If you're still curious & promise not to emulate this without taking measures to improve its safety, contact me & I'll show you.

In case you missed it: DO NOT MAKE THIS THING VIA 3D PRINTING. IT WILL BREAK/FAIL TO BRAKE, & IS UNSAFE.

http://www.tektro-usa.com/category.php?catid=188&productid=1096 Reference.

The only version that worked. Note the whitening at the corner. Very heavy, thick piece of steel, but still bent considerably under braking forces.
Use with a long 6 mm bolt so the head recesses, & a locknut or recessed nut if that's the kind of fork you have.

Since these are unsafe, use them only as decorative or reference models, or use CNC milling with aluminum at least. They are not usable when 3D printed.

Safety disclaimer: use at your own risk. The first three versions are completely unreliable when 3D printed. Do not try & brake with these. They will almost certainly break unless you machine them. Just inserting the 6 mm post bolt cracked the plastic axially.

description.text:
This is a customizable woodworking clamp cam. Log spirals can be used to hold a piece in one direction against thrust. Force is transferred directly to the hub since the tangent is always perpendicular to the radius. This is best used as a pair in opposite orientations to oppose bidirectional movement. If used as two pairs, immobilizes an object in the xy plane.

The low profile is useful with 2.5D router tables

This is a basic spool holder that uses four 628zz bearings. The half-sleeves are mounted on the bearings and they provide a good guide for the filament spool. Just mount all the bearings with the half sleeves like in the picture, using either a cut m8 threaded rod or m8 bolts and you should be fine.

I also included the sketchup files in case you need to make changes. The extra holes in the stand are mostly just to save up on filament and decrease print times, but you could use the ones on the bottom to fix the stand using m8 bolts.

The half sleeves should fit snug on the bearings, but in case they slip, just print the half sleeve at 99.5% and you should be fine, or add a bit of glue on the exterior of the bearing.

I had 1 out of 2 of these for a Trek Soho I was building up. I'm not even sure you can buy these through Trek, QBP, etc. If you could, they would cost more than they're worth. Just print your own.

For bikes with internally routed brake cables. Use like this: (https://www.google.com/search?q=brake+cable+internal+cover&rlz=1C1CHBD_enUS706US706&tbm=isch&imgil=gv6V44UDyzdYKM%253A%253B-sMU7JHtu8TFBM%253Bhttp%25253A%25252F%25252Fwww.mbr.co.uk%25252Fhow-to-2%25252Fsilence-bike-four-easy-steps-322631&source=iu&pf=m&fir=gv6V44UDyzdYKM%253A%252C-sMU7JHtu8TFBM%252C_&usg=__GHIOI4wRmJuxTEdjSu3VERSGPdQ%3D&biw=1270&bih=1330&ved=0ahUKEwirl5DOqe_QAhVN-2MKHWQ7BNAQyjcInQE&ei=2PFOWKvLF832jwPk9pCADQ#imgrc=us_0qkIyPScwcM%3A)

Look like this: https://www.google.com/search?q=brake+cable+internal+cover&rlz=1C1CHBD_enUS706US706&tbm=isch&imgil=fQsAKKEcqyR2GM%253A%253BVFBQZeL349IEEM%253Bhttp%25253A%25252F%25252Fwww.chainreactioncycles.com%25252Fvitus-bikes-zenium-internal-brake-cable-guide-2015%25252Frp-prod129590&source=iu&pf=m&fir=fQsAKKEcqyR2GM%253A%252CVFBQZeL349IEEM%252C_&usg=__18Flf00mRy-8UMy7W9d7fyRJkvQ%3D&biw=1270&bih=1330#imgrc=fQsAKKEcqyR2GM%3A

I guess people do sell them: https://www.aliexpress.com/store/product/10pcs-MTB-moutain-bike-frame-inner-line-clip-road-track-frame-brake-derailleur-internal-cable-guide/1930138_32627456158.html Best of luck if it fits your frame though.

This is not a cable stop. The housing just goes clear through. Designed from a Trek Soho brake cover that I did have. I lost the other one. It fit very well (no rattle, fairly tight) on the first try. It may only work on Trek bikes, I'm not sure. I saw a Felt Verza Speed with a cover that looked very similar. Not sure if it's universal or not.

Will need a decent amount of post processing to clean off the supports. Use a drill to clean the hole.

Obligatory safety warning since this has to do with your braking. Don't think it'll affect it at all, but use at your own risk. It literally just keeps the cable housing from rattling, but nonetheless.

title: Warmoon light cover + USB dynamo hub charging

description.text:
A light cover for the Warmoon MR16 light. Secures using zip ties about 0.2" wide.

https://www.amazon.com/Warmoon-Daylight-Dimmable-Spotlight-Equivalent/dp/B01DY1SO4A

I designed this as a waterproof (?) cover since I wanted to use this light in conjunction with my Sanyo NH-H27 dynamo hub (standard 6V/3W hub) for bike use (touring specifically). I think I tested it to fit okay. Never actually ended up using it. It would be easy to add features to make it mount to the handlebars or something.

Bonus dynamo hub USB charging:

You can unsolder the Warmoon light connections & use just the socket/circuitry to make a USB charging outlet with a car cigarette-style USB charger if you solder it correctly. You could add other stuff like a fuse to protect your load (phone, etc.).

Note that with this method, you are discarding the light itself. I haven't made something to use both the light & the USB charging. This light's circuitry converts the hub's AC power to DC, & the cigarette charger regulates it to 5V for most USB devices (I think).

I'm terrible with electronics, so do this at your own risk. I have tried this setup before & I couldn't tell if I was getting a net charge, although a cell phone did confirm that it was receiving power.

The stuff labeled "Housing Final" is pertinent to housing the electronics necessary to complete this dynamo USB charging stuff. It has a USB outlet on one end & a small hole to fit a charging LED indicator light that came on the cigarette lighter I used.

Also uses 0.2" zipties to close the covers together. You could use hot glue to seal it pretty well, I think. I haven't printed/tested this latter design.

description.text:
UPDATE 2: After getting my 3D printer up and running, Gyroscope! has turned out to be quite a pain. It did manage to print, but ONLY WITH SUPPORTS, and after putting it together, it has become a massive failure due to horrible friction in the bearings for no reason. Also, the inner spinner cannot fit inside the frame, so a new file is needed before a successful make can be attempted. I may upload one, but who knows.

UPDATE: After some thought, I've added what I think will make this even better, which is more inertia! A new file has been added called "Gyroscope solid_Nickel Spinner," which allows four nickels to be tightly tucked into the spinner disk (with the convenience of easy removal, as well), adding way more power to the gyroscope. I may upload a file soon with the body and nickel spinner combined, but for now you can add both pieces to your slicer and arrange them yourself in a printable fashion. Happy printing!

I HAVE NOT PRINTED THIS AS OF UPLOADING. My hot end is clogged to kingdom come, and while my new one is on the way, I finished up this redesign of the official TEDCO gyroscope. It's quite a challenging design with all the concentric parts, but I believe this will print without support, aside from a nice brim on the printbed.

Two 608 bearings are needed to attach the spinner to the gyroscope body, and a string for spinning and pulling the gyroscope is needed as well. The dimensions are EXACTLY the right size of the bearing, in theory, but depending on the accuracy of your printer, it might be a tight fit.

Should probably note that I'm also an inexperienced CADder using 123D Design, but I feel like I'm getting pretty good at it, so this might turn out alright.

author: moconnor1978

description.text:
Shim that adapts the much more common 1.125" (1 1/8") threadless stems to clamp on to 1" steerers.

Cut down to match the height of your stem, or if smaller, make it the largest percentage below 100% possible. It would be much better to just go in the SLDPRT & extrude it further, then remove the excess.

Do not just leave this larger than the height of your stem or else the threadless adjustment doesn't actually work. Use 1" headset spacers (I uploaded these) for the rest of the steerer. If you leave it larger, the cap may compress shim against the bearings through the compression ring too much & give you terrible steering quality.

Never tested/printed. Use at your own risk. The plastic probably doesn't have enough room to deform & crack, & I think it's pretty good in compression, but it could break & prevent you from steering your bike, which is bad. Aluminum shims are readily available cheaply, so I would prefer to stake my life on those instead.

This was a failed design for an electronic shifting project I was working on. It's a mount plus other stuff for a standard servo to mount to the driveside chainstay of a bike & use it to actuate the rear derailleur using a standard shift cable.

It is used in addition to the user's current RD.

We tried this with the highest torque servo we had (about 20 kgf cm, I think), & it was far too weak for a double spring old Shimano 105 rear derailleur. I think we tried with more modern long cage Shimano Claris RD (single spring) & it still was too weak.

Incidentally, many months after I designed this, this appeared:

  • https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/1598276649/xshifter-worlds-first-universal-wireless-smart-shi
  • http://www.xshifter.com/

Which mounts similarly, & actuates similarly. I haven't played with them & I'm not sure how they got a strong enough servo/linear actuator, but they cost too much for me to find out.

Since it actuates over a very short cable length with no considerable bends, the reduced friction should permit pretty good quality, if it worked.
17 Dec 2016: Uploaded some PDFs & images demonstrating how the assembly comes to together.

Uses zipties & inner tube shims to mount to the seatstay.

Need some small screws, don't know the threading or size.

You will need an additional aluminum (sheet metal) servo mount. I think a CAD of that is provided. It came with the servo we had; I never tried to buy one, so I don't know anything about availability.

comments.text: I've been thinking about making one myself, but was never able to work out the specs for the servo. One thing that might help is that you balance the pull of the return spring in the derailleur with another spring pulling the other way in the shifter. That way the motor just has to overcome the friction.

This print requires 3.77 meters of plastic at 50% density. For myself, I estimated the unit cost to be $0.49 with ABS. The OEM piece was ABS.

Finishing

This object should fit directly in the original bay bezel spot. The front could be sanded to achieve a smoother appearance.

Background Information

The original bezel on one of our 5800s cracked. I attempted to fix it with epoxy. The epoxy held for about a week. Unfortunately, if you lay the tower down on a desk and sit the keyboard in front of it, the corner of the keyboard is the same height as the bezel. It can be accidentally pushed into the bezel.

I measured an original one with dial calipers. I then drew the object in AutoCad 2011. I printed a prototype and decided that I wasn't satisfied with the strength of the objects. So, I added a vertical support in the middle and added .02 to the thickness so I could sand the front for a smoother appearance.

description.text:
In this project 6th grade students create busts of famous figures from the Renaissance. This is the second year of the project, the original project is here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1190879

The models were with a height of about 70 mm, some will require support. The models were painted so the student didn't always model features like eyes and hair in 3D. These could be painted on later.

Also included are a printed crown and neck ruffle that can be added to figures.

The "pineapple" and "banana" shape generators on Tinkercad are good for creating moustaches and beards.
NGSS

This is part of a cross-curricular project on the renaissance that includes art, history, and literature. As part of the project each student researched a famous figure from the renaissance. They created a "fakebook" page for their figure (instructions for this part of the project are included along with examples). The renaissance fair also includes food, music, and games. This project is done near Christmas, so the students also decorate a gingerbread castle for their characters.
For the 3D part of the project they created a bust of their figure. These were printed with a height of about 70 mm and painted.

• Each student selected an important person from the Renaissance as the subject for their project.
  • Students researched the life of their subject
  • Students created a "fakebook" page for their subject (see lesson outline and example)
  • Students created a 3D bust of their subject using Tinkercad
  • Busts were printed at a scale of about 70 mm tall
  • Busts were painted in art class
    • When designing the bust students were encourage not to try to model relatively flat features like eyes and hair, these can be well represented with paint. The half sphere and parabaloid shapes work well for the torso. The sphere can be used for the head. The "banana" and "pineapple" shape generators are good for making moustaches and beards. I printable neck ruffle and crown are included here for download if necessary.

The more successful cousin of the cable-actuated servo mount. Mounts directly to a regular road-style derailleur (think Shimano). Won't mount to Shimano mountain Shadow-style RDs, or funky SRAM RDs either. Can also mount to older Shimano STX-like RDs that stlil have a road-style parallelogram body.

There was a lot of flex in this system, so it definitely wasn't perfect. I think the barrel adjuster mount broke once.

I've ridden this before, & it was okay. A lot of improvements could be made both on the hardware & software side. I can't help you with the software side too much though.

You must disable/cut the central spring or springs in the RD for this to work. You can use a medium strength servo with this. I recommend only using a single spring RD so you can actually disable/cut it.

Mounts by connecting to the barrel adjuster, & the horn actuates at the cable clamp.

It's important that the servo axis is positioned right over the top left pin on the parallelogram mechanism (if you're looking from the bottom of the derailleur, when it's mounted on the bike) to get the best results.
17 Dec 2016: Added images & other stuff to help visualize how the assembly comes together.

author: JasonGarf

print_settings.Notes:: all parts printed in PLA, I was going to use ABS but after a couple of prototype prints I found that PLA was more than capable of supplying me with the quality and strength of parts Id need and its alot less troublesome material to print on mass with...... plus I could get hold of it in GOLD at the time and I had my heart dead set on the new frame using Gold after using Silver on the original (yes I know thats a tad superficial but I dont care)

description.text:
basically these are all the parts required to upgrade my original PolTur Printer design to the PolTur XL.

the original:-
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1792378

benefits of opting for this upgrade:

incredibly rigid frame pretty much eliminates any and all vibration (secondary effect of drastically reducing noise also, Im constantly nipping into my workroom to check that the printers still running cos I cant hear the bloody thing anymore)

Designed around the ever popular Lack Table which makes enclosing the entire printer a very simple affair.

printbed size increased from the original 200x200x170 to 300x200x200 with ED3 type extruder and 250x200x200 with Mk7/Mk8 extruder.

remarkably portable, with the frame and table integrated together the whole printer can be picked up and moved with relative ease without disturbing the printers delicate calibrations

with the rigidity of the frame Ive been able to increase the print speed without any notable effects to print quality (Ive so far increased speed 20% from stock speed)

overhead spool mounting, multi spool capable (upto 4x standard 1kg spools)

frame sections utilize 15x15mm Alu square tube which is easy to cut, drill & bolt (you can opt to use the CF tubing I originally used on the first PolTur design but the Alu tube is remarkably cheaper in comparison)

Design still utilizes the original Printrite hardware with the only exception being the addition of 400mmx8mm smooth rods on the Y-axis(to allow the new 300mm build area size) and 350mm lead screws (to allow for the increase in build height)

Im sure theres more benefits to the upgrade that Im forgetting but by far the most important (even more so than the increase of printable size).....

..... it looks the dogs gonads on my workbench.

I apologise in advance for not adding the parts individually to thingiverse but tbf, it'll only take 5 minutes for the builder to separate them all in Slic3r (or Cura etc)

hope anyone considering the original PolTur will like this new Upgrade, I know Im loving it right now.

enjoy.

addon's / improvements / modifications

300x200 heated printbed - https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2152660

bearingless carriage - https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2516300

ramps 1.4 enclosure and screen mount -

https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2516300

description.text:
Follow the picture on how to assemble, it is pretty straight forward.

Just use some 12mm M4 screws to hold them together.

A failed experiment on how to actuate a rear derailleur with a servo. The servo would be mounted to the barrel adjuster, & a rod passed through the barrel adjuster.

The rod would have teeth, & the servo would draw the rod in/out using a rack & pinion drive.

The rod would be connected to a plate with a non-circular slot in it to constrain a pin located in the cable anchor bolt hole.

This way, the circular movement of the servo would cause the parallelogram mechanism to force a lateral movement.

The design problem here is that the rod is about 0.115" thick & would bend immediately. Unless you drill out the barrel adjuster & stiffen it up considerably, this design is kind of useless. You can play with the motion (I think) in the assembly file.

If you actually manage to make this work, please let me know. I'd be intrigued.

Plastic-white and clear acrylic sheets Based on the scale graphic I found on the internet. Total cutting time is ~4 hours on an 80 watt laser I apologize for the photos. Thingiverse insists on cropping my photos or rotating them if I try to post them in the proper aspect ratio...

This model is designed to slot together with a minimum of glue. The solid base plate is stacked and glues with two layers of the slot panels into which the main side panels and side shim panels fit. The panels labeled "Police Public Call Box" are double side stick-taped to the main panels. The top lamp fixture press-fits together and is made of 4 clear acrylic pieces. The white acrylic window panes are hot glued to the interior panel. The blue color is Krylon "Regal Blue" spray paint. The Lamp is powered by a 9 volt AA battery pack attached to a white LED via a toggle switch and resistor.

title: USB-B Connector Shell
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Simple USB-B connector shell for use with replacement USB-B connectors.

Background - I use the Arduino UNO for many projects and I prefer to provide power with a regulated 5V power supply via the USB connector. It bypasses the thermally challenged on board regulator and is over current protected. So I find a cheap (or handy scrap box) 5V power adapter, cut the cable to length and add a USB-B connector. I made this simple slip over cover to finish the connector which were cheap but lacked a shell.

So if you also have a handful of naked USB-B connectors - here is a shell that may dress them up.

8" Pepper mill/grinder housing to be used in conjunction with pepper grinder mechanism found here: http://www.amazon.com/Peppermill-Grinding-Mechanism-Shaft-Woodturning/dp/B00A6YFY4C/ref=sr_1_7?ie=UTF8&qid=1386199915&sr=8-7&keywords=pepper+grinder+kit+8. I was going to buy one or make one out of wood but decided this would be a way to show the utility of a 3D printer. If only the grinder mechanism didn't cost so much because I only used ~$6.75 in material cost. I printed the object on my Ultimaker 1 in ColorFabb XT but PLA would work fine too. This is my first attempt at this grinder and I am sure it could be optimized to look better, use less material, and probably function better. I included the SolidWorks part files so take it and make some better derivations!

Printed in ColorFabb XT material on my Ultimaker 1 with the following print settings: Layer Height - 0.2mm
Shell Thickness - 1.2mm
Bottom/Top Thickness - 1mm
Fill Density - 20%
Print Speed - 50mm/s
Print Temperature - 240C Orient the designs so the top part is standing on its top (where there is the largest fillet). The bottom part should stand on its top (where there are two cylinders to start). The picture in the gallery should explain the orientation if this is unclear. No support or scaling should be needed and it should work well in PLA (just lower the temp to ~215C at the same speed). The shell thickness is important because the screw holes are designed to be threaded into (so you need 1+mm of material for the thread engagement). This print took a while (10hrs) but I am sure someone can come up with either a more efficient design or push up the temperature and speed to print faster. Update 1: After printing, everything works great. It could stand to be just a few mm shorter in its overall length just so the coarse grind setting has a few more threads engaged on the top nut. Scaling down in the Z direction should work. Update 2: I re-sized the original file and reduce the Pepper Grinder Base height by ~2.5mm which should solve the issue noted in Update 1.

This is a basic filament cleaning holder, designed to fit the Voltivo filament sponges.

I designed this to snugly fit the Voltivo sponge while not effecting filament movement. There are little 'dimple pinches' on the inner walls to help pinch the sponge in place. There is also a small dimple on the bottom of the holder, to provide a small reservoir in case you get a little overzealous with your 'drops' of oil.

I'm using this with 1.75mm filament and working fine.

If you don't have a Voltivo sponge, you can cut your sponge own to fit and this will work for you just as well!

print_settings.Notes:: These pieces have a tendency to pop off of the bed if it is not warm enough, or melt if it is too hot. We found that 87º was a good medium, and with plenty of hairspray, the pieces printed just fine. The cylinder is not part of the puzzle, but during printing, it allows the tower on one of the pieces to cool enough and not warp. It is not necessary to print the puzzle, but recommended.

description.text: This is a 3x3x3 cubic puzzle assembled using 3 non-identical pieces. Our model demonstrates a few key mathematical concepts, specifically, sequences, problem solving, and different geometries. The model has one sequence for assembly, but can be assembled in either direction. The use of logic and problem solving skills are required in both the creation of new puzzles, and the solving of existing puzzles. With the creation of each new cube, a unique geometric figure is created. It is unique in both the sense that all of the pieces are different and that the sequence for assembly uses different techniques.

Printer Brand:

SeeMeCNC

Printer:

Rostock MAX

Notes:

These pieces have a tendency to pop off of the bed if it is not warm enough, or melt if it is too hot. We found that 87º was a good medium, and with plenty of hairspray, the pieces printed just fine. The cylinder is not part of the puzzle, but during printing, it allows the tower on one of the pieces to cool enough and not warp. It is not necessary to print the puzzle, but recommended.

This cube was based off of Thingiverse user richgain's model "Printable Interlocking Puzzle." Using his 3 piece puzzle design, we used Rhino to create our version of the puzzle. This involved creating rectangular prisms and using the Boolean Union function in the program. After printing a test-run, we quickly realized that our design did not account for the space necessary between each piece in order for the puzzle to fit together properly. In order to fix this problem, adjustments were made to our design by creating larger gaps in each piece of the puzzle. This was accomplished by using the Wire Cut function in the program to shave 1-2 millimeters off of every gap on each piece.

This is my second (big) project - Half Life / Half Life 2
The height of the characters is 14 - 14.5 cm, the other objects are proportional to the characters.

Printed all parts on the Monoprice MP Select Mini, glued it together and painted it - special thanks to my girlfriend who helped me with the colours! The crate was printed with wood "Original Oak" for realistic surface.

These were my first experiences in the design program MeshMixer and paint a figure. The face is very difficult, but I am satisfied, I just started with painting 5 months ago.

Enjoy it and Merry Christmas!
PS: Sorry for the poor photo quality!

You can use the complete figure OR the splitted Files (zip-archiv) and glue the parts together. However, the [Character]-"Weapon" always needed.

This is the part that made my wife excited about 3D printing.

Print two of these, one of them mirrored (I did this in my slicer). These provide a snug fit onto the metal strip on one of my refrigerator door shelves. Before replacing the original parts (which were slightly damaged) with these, the contents of the shelf would frequently crash onto the floor. Our refrigerator is a Kenmore, but I'm not sure of the model.

Two files are included: the STL as well as the SketchUp design file. The SketchUp file may need to be adjusted for your particular repair job. I'd recommend using ABS or another suitably tough material. The parts I printed were a bit tight and required some sanding and filing.

Printer Brand:

SeeMeCNC

Printer:

Rostock MAX

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20% - 50%

Notes:

Printed with the sloped face toward the bed, as modeled in SketchUp. This sloped face was not laid flat on the bed. Instead, the sloped face was held up with a raft and support. The face opposite the sloped face was horizontal and parallel to the bed. I chose to orient the part this way to make the small tabs as strong as possible, since these were the parts that broke on the original parts.

The material was natural ABS.

title: Amazon Basics USB3.0 Hub Raspberry Zero Case

description.text:
Borrowed the raspberry case from DotNetWorker, but since I havn't had much luck printing snap fits in PLA, my lid is designed to be taped or glued in place.

This is a case for the zero which fits an off the shelf powered usb hub, that most people should be able to get, for now :P

I've used an amazon basics powered hub : https://www.amazon.co.uk/gp/product/B00E0NH7DQ/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o04_s02?ie=UTF8&psc=1

Assembly Guide:

Step 1
: Take the hub apart, be careful not to snap off the delicate components insdide

Step 2
: Cut off the usb plug about 5mm off the board, we won't need it, just leave enough to see the colors of the wires.

Step 3
: Solder PP22 to the backside of the usbhub where the green wire goes in (USB D+)
: Solder PP23 to the backside of the usbhub where the white wire goes in (USB D-)
: Solder PP1 to the backside of the usbhub where the red wire goes in (USB +)
: Solder PP1 to the TopSide of the usbhub where the powerplug goes in,
the positive pin is the pad at the edge of the board which connects to the center pin on the plug (measure it to be sure)
: Solder PP6 to the backside of the usbhub where the black wire goes in (USB -)

You can find a few guides on how to do the above in great detail if you google a bit.

Printer:

MOD-T

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.4

Infill:

100

Notes:

I tried lowering the speed to 20m/s in cura, but it still messed it up proper.

title: Pieces for all DOG games and TAC

description.text:
Do you like to play DOG or any variation of it? Like to always play your favorite color, wherever you sit at the table? Then print your own and put it together as you like!

With these files you can create all boards and pieces for these games:
DOG, DOG royal, Black DOG and TAC.
Some additional files are included for accessories.

What you need
for DOG, TAC and DOG Royal (4 players):

  • 4x DOG Segment 135°
  • 4x DOG home (all different colors)

for DOG, TAC and DOG Royal (6 players):

  • same as for 4 players plus
  • 2x DOG home (all different colors)

  • 2x DOG Segment 90°

    optional:
    If you play with spherical beads (mine have a diameter of 13.5 mm)

    • 4x (or 6x) DOG Bank fuer Kugel

      Without beads you can also print the pieces

    • 1 "DOG Narr Kugel" in black for Black DOG
    • 4-5 in every color of "DOG Narr Kugel" for DOG, Black DOG and TAC
      or
    • 1 in every color of "DOG Narr Kugel", "DOG Bauer Kugel", "DOG Ritter Kugel" and "DOG Koenig Kugel" for DOG Royal

for Black DOG (4 players):

  • 4x DOG Segment 135°
  • 4x Black DOG home (all different colors)
  • 2x Black DOG Drehpunkte oben
  • 2x Black DOG Drehpunkte unten
  • 1x Black DOG Drehscheibe
  • 1x Black DOG Drehscheiben-Aufnahme 3

The "DOG Teile-Halter" can be used to stack the board pieces in a box so that they don't scramble.

Please note if you want to play all of the games you can also use the "Black DOG home" instead of the "DOG home" pieces for all the other games - but not vice versa.

Also note that the player's starting point for DOG, DOG Royal and TAC is different from Black DOG. You just need to flip over the entire board for that.

title: Indirect Light Fixture Kit
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This is an indirect lighting fixture that I designed to fit over a single gang wall box for permanent installation, or to be used with a lamp cord for less permanent installs. The kit consists of a wall bracket/electrical box that holds two standard Leviton 9874 porcelain lamp bases, a fascia bracket to mount to the back of the lighting baffle, and a 80mm x 80mm template to make mounting it level easy and quick.

The lighting baffle can be a material of your choice; in this case I used a piece of pine with a nice grain, but the bracket is strong enough to support most any wood you would chose to use.

Materials List:

Printed Parts:
1x - Bracket Box
1x - Fascia Bracket
1x - Wall Mount Template (Optional)

Non Printed Parts:
1x - User selected baffle/shade material (In the above shown installation I used a 26" x 6" piece of pine. Any wood, metal, or plastic can be used.)
2x - Leviton 9874 porcelain lamp bases (https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00134U13I/ref=oh_aui_search_detailpage?ie=UTF8&psc=1 )
2x - M3x16 Screw
2x - Lightbulbs
1x - 8ft Lamp Cord (Optional, not required if hard wiring)
4x - M4x16 Screws
4x - M4 Nuts
4x - Screws (will vary depending on baffle/shade material)
1x - Nail (Optional, only used if using wall mount template)
4x - Wall anchors and screws (As appropriate to your wall material application.)

Instructions: Use wall mount template to determine desired location of light fixture. Use a nail to hang template by central hole. Allow to hang freely as to allow for leveling. Once leveled mark the four hole locations. Remove and discard template. Install wall bracket box into location marked with wall anchors. Install porcelain lamp bases and wire to power or lamp cord. (Please note that I am not a professional electrician and have intentionally omitted specific wiring instructions. Please consult your local regulations on electrical power and installation before installing this fixture.) After the wall bracket is installed center and mount the fascia bracket to the back of the piece of baffle/shade material that you have selected with 4 screws. Install light bulbs into the sockets then slide the fascia bracket into the face of the bracket box. Use an M3 screw at the top and bottom of the bracket box to secure the fascia to the bracket box.

That's it! I intended this to be used with a pair of Phillips Hue bulbs for maximum flexibility but any bulb will do. This fixture can be made to look as rustic or modern as the room decor warrants since the baffle/shade material is completely independent of the printed pieces. Additionally, I've included mounting holes on the bottom of the bracket if you prefer a more traditional light box style front, bottom, and sides baffle. This fixture provides indirect lighting ideal for use in areas with reflective surfaces otherwise prone to glare such as home theaters and galleries.

Printer:

FlashForge Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.1mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Make sure to print at 100% infill as this is a load bearing piece. The bracket box should be printed with the wall side down. Because all overhangs are 45 degrees I did not need supports to successfully print it.

description.text: If you have a 2016 Newmar Ventana Motorhome...and have added the ever so popular Oxygenics Shower head... You may notice the shower wand is a bit loose in the adjustable shower bar holder. 3D printing to the rescue. I have created an adapter that slips onto the tapered end of the Oxygenics Shower Wand. We have the Brushed Nickel Finish Oxygenics Shower head. The adapter allows a much tighter fit when installed into the adjustable shower bar spray wand holder. Print one...see if it fits. IF you like it...you might want to tack it to the shower wand with hot glue so that it stays with the wand...and doesn't fall off when taking the wand out of the holder.

title: Variable Multi Filament Spool Holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A spool holder which can hold some more spools than usual ones. The width is only limited by the length of the aluminium pipes you can get or the size of your room. My current one is 90cm in width and can hold 2 x 4 spools.

Every spool between 12 and 35+ cm should work fine as long the side walls of the spool are not more than 5.5-6mm in width.

The single parts can slide easily on the aluminium pipes to fit you spools width.

Non-printed parts:

  • Aluminium pipe 10 x 1 mm x "as long as you want"... (If you live in the middle of Europe you very likely will find "Alfer" aluminium pipes in your hardware store. That are the ones you need)
  • Ball bearings (10 x 15 x 4) - Four for each spool

Printing parts:

  • 2 x Ends
  • 2 x Single for each spool

If the spool holder is more than 40cm in width or/and has to carry very heavy spools i recommend to also print one (or more) supports.

Printer:

Prusa i3 MK2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No
You may have to sand the holes of the sliding parts a bit to fit perfectly, but also not to much.

At first: I didn't print it out yet because I'm waiting for my 3D-printer for almost 2 weeks now. So I really don't know if this prints well or not. I'd be very happy if you try it out or just comment this for the 8 hours of work I put into this. (This is my very first selfmade design. Before, I only sketched 3D-designs for education and these where just some simple things like pyramids with holes in it or something).

So now to the Instructions:
The buttontips are meant to be printed twice. One for reset and the other one for the powerbutton. The small part that looks like a lightning is just a little piece of decoration that will be made out of transparent, flexible filament to fit into the same shaped whole in the front of the casing. This has to be glued into and illuminated by two smd-led's in the inside, which fit into the 2 small holes. To complete the whole thing you'll have to create two 106mm x 121mm x 2mm plates out of whatever you want (I use acrylic glass). Then you only have to fix the lattepanda and the sideplates with some screws and nuts and add a 35mm x 35mm fan (if you want). There should be enough space for the lattepanda with its cpu-fan and/or some passive coolers.

I hope it worked fine for you and have fun with it!

I released the v.2 of the lattepanda case!

It is basicly the same case, but it's split into 7 pieces. After you've printed them, you can easily stick them together and prepare them with acetone.
It is way much easier to print and fullend then the one before.

title: Guassian Geiger Alien math pattern thing

description.text:
huge thing fits in cura probably fits in slicer 64, found it in fractal art open source google results for black and white. CC1 hightmap 2 stl program and then netfabb.

NOTE: I learned that reprap filament printers don't like printing irregular fractals, only ones with simple curves and lines, otherwise the tray tends to vibrate a lot and the filament goes back and forth and makes a blobby and ugly print. So, if it's ona filament printer and it looks like there are many small details on the fractal, and it's a reprap or something or a standard extruder, it will look low quality.

moore_constellation

A cluster of small telescopes, doing autonomous science work
Project named to the honor of Sir Patrick Moore

Description

Using a collection of cheap and autonomous telescopes to do task such as

  • Variable star astrometry
  • Exoplanet confirmation
  • Moon meteorite monitoring
  • Astrophotography

Parts of the project

  1. Autonomous mini-observatories: Consists of a motorized telescope with a camera, with a motorized dome and climate sensors
  2. INDI compatible software for controlling each mini-observatory
  3. Kstars for controlling the mini-observatories and asign tasks to them
  4. Normalization software that will agregate results from several observatories to add to the power of the telescopes as well as to add scientific value to the observations

Work already prototyped

  • Cloud sensors using 90° IR Thermometer. The dome should close then clouds are detected
  • 3d part for conecting a DSLR camera to the focuser of the telescope. (It is probable an NoIR-Pi cam will be used)
  • 3d part to hold focuser, it has the contour of the telescope and screw holes with secondary mirror space

Work being done

  • 3d part for the focuser, with mini-stepper motor and rail. I'm currently tryng with a motorized linear rail potenciometer, but later with mini-stepper with included rails
  • Webcams as well as Pi-cams are being evaluated
  • Integration with focus software

My proudest memory as a child was when my master teacher, my Dad, and I made an astonishing Pinewood Derby car from scratch, fully painted in detail. title: Hose Adapter for Home Protect Easy Home Dehumdifier

description.text: This adapter is to connect a standard 100mm semi-rigid air-conditioner hose to a EasyHome Home Protect dehumidifier so you can duct the dry air where it's needed. To fit you must (carefully!) remove the air deflector flap from the the outlet grill of the dehumidifier, the adapter will clip into the pegs that hold the air deflector.

Protège hélices pour QX 95 inspiré des Prop Guard de Boopidoo pour QX 90, retravaillées pour s'adapter à un QX95

I attached the CAD files too.

J'ai aussi joint le fichier CAO 3D .

title: Support for Spring Tension Shower Rod

description.text: This is a support for a spring tension shower rod. As these rods tend to fall down if you hang things on them, I created this small support. It has a wedge-shape, so the round rod will have two contact points with it, to distribute forces. Because of this, the print dimensions don't have to be exact. This support is 4 cm wide, allowing the use of two strips of 19 mm wide two-sided tape to fix it to the wall.
